title: 111_s4045
content: The Act may be cited as the "Armed Career Criminal Sentencing Act of 2010". Congress acknowledges that armed career criminals are individuals with prior criminal convictions and possession of a firearm, deemed particularly dangerous. The purpose of section 924(e) of title 18, United States Code, is to provide severe punishment for these offenders and protect the public from the risks they pose. The Supreme Court requires district courts to use a "categorical approach" to determine if prior convictions warrant an enhanced sentence. The Supreme Court's "categorical approach" under section 924(e) limits judges to reviewing the language of prior convictions, leading to inconsistent sentencing and burdening the judicial system. The Court's concern about right-to-jury-trial issues restricts a more thorough inquiry into prior convictions. The statutory maximum sentence under section 922(g) of title 18, United States Code, has been increased to life imprisonment. Despite efforts by Federal prosecutors, there have been instances where armed career criminals were not sentenced as intended due to limitations imposed by the Supreme Court's "categorical approach" under section 924(e). The determination of whether State and local offenses qualify as crimes of violence or serious drug trafficking offenses has led to costly and time-consuming litigation due to disparities in State criminal laws. Congress believes in the need for more uniform sentencing provisions under section 924(e) to ensure equality, fair treatment, and public safety. Federal judges should have the authority to determine if a conviction warrants enhancement, allowing them to fulfill their traditional sentencing roles. This Act aims to lower the maximum sentence to empower judges in making sentencing judgments as per the Constitution of the United States. This Act aims to lower the maximum sentence under section 924(e) to 25 years and increase the maximum sentence under section 922(g) to 25 years, allowing judges to exercise sentencing discretion without implicating Apprendi principles. Congress anticipates minimal changes in sentences for non-armed career criminals under section 922(g). The Act aims to lower the maximum sentence under section 924(e) to 25 years and increase the maximum sentence under section 922(g) to 25 years. Prosecutors have discretion to decide whether to use prior convictions to enhance penalties. The Act aims to lower the maximum sentence under section 924(e) to 25 years and increase the maximum sentence under section 922(g) to 25 years. Prosecutors have discretion to decide whether to use prior convictions to enhance penalties. SEC. 3. DEFINITION. Section 924(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to define 'qualifying offense' as a serious drug offense or any crime punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year, including juvenile delinquency involving firearms, knives, or destructive devices. The definition of 'qualifying offense' under Section 924(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code includes crimes punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year, such as burglary, arson, or extortion. The definition of a 'qualifying offense' under Section 924(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code includes crimes involving the use of physical force against another person or resulting in serious bodily injury. The definition of a 'qualifying offense' under Section 924(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code includes crimes involving the unlawful manufacture, possession, use, sale, transfer, importation, or distribution of an explosive or explosive device, nuclear or chemical material, or a weapon of mass destruction. The bill modifies the definition of a 'qualifying offense' under Section 924(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code to include offenses that pose a serious risk of bodily injury to another or result in serious bodily injury to another. It also updates sentencing guidelines. Section 924 of title 18, United States Code is amended to increase penalties for knowingly violating section 922(g) to a fine, imprisonment up to 25 years, or both. Additionally, the bill updates the definition of 'qualifying offenses' under Section 924(e)(2) to include offenses that pose a serious risk of bodily injury or result in serious bodily injury to another, along with updating sentencing guidelines. No person convicted of an offense under section 922(g) can be sentenced to the mandatory minimum term of years unless the United States attorney files an information with the court before trial, stating previous convictions. The court can consider facts of previous convictions, not just elements of the statute of conviction. Proceedings follow procedures under the Controlled Substances Act. The court can consider previous convictions by reviewing judicial records, presentence reports, or other evidence to determine if the person has prior convictions. The determination must be made by a preponderance of the evidence. SEC. 5. DIRECTIVE TO UNITED STATES SENTENCING COMMISSION. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and revise the Federal Sentencing Guidelines and policy statements related to offenses under section 924(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, in response to an amendment to section 924(e)(2)(B) of title 18, United States Code. This includes revising the definition of "crime of violence" and sections 4B1.1 and 4B1.4 of the Federal Sentencing Guidelines. The sentencing court can use all reliable evidence to determine if a prior conviction qualifies as an offense under section 924(e)(2)(B) of title 18, United States Code.
